title: Neuroscience of Obesity
content: Research has focused on the neuroscience of obesity and energy homeostasis. The role of leptin and the genes that regulate fat mass and obesity have been discussed. The hedonic aspects of food and how our taste today is different than what our ancestors tasted have been explored. Energy and chloric density relate to taste and how we potentially select foods. The energy balance model, the carbohydrate insulin model, and unifying theories around adiposity have been discussed.

title: Obesity Through History
content: Obesity has changed phenotypically over the last thousand years. Specifically looking at US rates of obesity over the past 150 years, humans are much fatter today than they were 1000 years ago. Obesity was prevalent among the wealthy 1000 years ago, probably for similar reasons that we have obesity today. The prevalence of obesity was much lower then. Body Mass Index (BMI) has been used to measure obesity. 120-130 years ago only a few percent of people had a BMI > 30. Today 9-10% of adults have a BMI > 35.

title: Obesity and Adverse Health Outcomes
content: Obesity is associated with adverse health outcomes. There is lots of evidence that excess body fat contributes to all kinds of diseases: type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, certain cancers. However, there is a paradox where higher body fatness is seen as protective. This is due to the fact that people who are sick often lose weight, making leanness look worse than it really is. One method to get around this issue is the maximum attained weight method, which correlates the heaviest a person has ever been with their health outcomes.

title: Increase in Obesity Rates
content: Obesity rates have sharply increased across demographics. In the 60s, around 12% of the population was obese, compared to 43% today. The increase in obesity rates began somewhere in the range of 1976-1984. During this time period, big changes happened to the diet. More than half of US adults will be classified as actually having obesity at some point in their life if the current context is maintained.

title: Prevalence of Type 2 Diabetes and Obesity
content: Over the last 50 years, the prevalence of type 2 diabetes has increased 5-fold. In developed nations, obesity is no longer a condition of affluence at the individual level. There is still not a lot of obesity in the poorest people in the world, such as subsistence farmers in Sub-Saharan Africa. However, there is no demographic in the United States that has not gotten a lot fatter over the last few decades.

title: The Hypothalamus and Its Role in Obesity
content: The hypothalamus, a small part of the brain that specializes in homeostasis or maintaining the stability of body systems, plays a crucial role in obesity. It regulates body temperature and contains a regulatory system for body fat mass. The hypothalamus determines if you have the amount of fat it wants you to have. If you deviate from that, it starts to engage a coordinated series of physiological and behavioral responses to restore the previous level of body fat.

title: The Role of the Hormone Leptin in Obesity
content: Leptin is a hormone that circulates in proportion to your body fat mass. The hypothalamus measures the level of leptin in your circulation. Leptin is made in the adipocyte and secreted in proportion to body fat mass. The more adipose tissue you have, the more leptin you have. Leptin is also strongly impacted by short-term energy balance. There are leptin receptors in many parts of the body, but the ones that are relevant for body weight regulation are in the brain.

title: Explaining Leptin Resistance
content: Leptin resistance is a concept that has been invoked to explain why people with obesity have so much leptin and it’s not suppressing their excess body fat mass. So in the same way that people can develop insulin resistance where it takes more insulin to do the physiological jobs in the body, people with obesity require more leptin for the hypothalamus to be satisfied.

title: The Genetic Component of Obesity
content: Studies in identical twins show obesity has a heritability of 0.7. This level of heritability tells you that something is very, very genetically predetermined. So even though 100 years ago, virtually none of us were obese, today your lifetime incidence of obesity if 50%. Our genes haven’t changes in 100 years, so clearly our susceptibility for obesity has been with us for a great period of time and is highly preserved.

title: Genome-wide Association Studies and Body Mass Index
content: Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) are used to identify genetic markers, called SNPs (single-nucleotide polymorphisms), that correlate with differences in body mass index (BMI). These studies require large sample sizes and tremendous statistical power to detect anything with a high level of confidence. So far, GWAS have identified 900 genetic variants that suggest differences in BMI between individuals are genetically very complex. BMI is determined by a lot of different genes with very small effect sizes. The combination of these genes determines whether an individual is susceptible or not to obesity in a fattening environment.

title: Genetic Variants and Brain Biology
content: Studies have shown that the biology of BMI is heavily enriched for brain-related biology. This suggests that differences in body fatness between individuals are primarily determined by differences in how the brain is constructed and how it operates. People with obesity promoting genes tend to have greater eating drive and lower satiety. However, the exact way these genes affect the brain and impact body fatness is not yet fully understood.

title: Human Fat Storage and Evolution
content: Humans have a remarkable ability to store fat, which was essential for survival in environments where food and energy were scarce. Low leptin levels, which signal a lack of energy, would trigger the need to eat and store energy. Apart from energy, other nutrients and vitamins are important, and the lack of them is also a source of mortality. Humans have more fat than our closest primate relatives, suggesting our physiology is special in our capacity for fat storage.

title: Food and Brain Reward Circuits
content: Modern diets, which are often high in calorie-dense, refined foods, can alter our brain's reward circuits. Once exposed to these highly-preferred foods, less preferred, healthier foods no longer satisfy or motivate us in the same way. This makes it difficult for people raised in an environment of tasty, calorie-dense, easy-to-eat food to switch to a diet similar to our ancestors. The optimal concentration of nutrients, not their absolute amount, seems to be key for enjoyment and reinforcement, releasing dopamine that sets our motivational drive and helps form habits.

title: Sugar and Fat in Foods
content: If you removed the sugar from ice cream, it probably wouldn’t taste bad but it wouldn’t be nearly as good. If you removed the fat, it also wouldn’t be as good; fat-free ice cream isn’t exactly flying off the shelves. It’s the combination of sugar and fat really put it over the top. Foods commonly associated with strong cravings and addictive-like behavior are generally a combination of carbohydrate and fat.

title: Human Body's Response to Nutrients
content: Energy for humans primarily comes from carbohydrate and fat. We get a list: carbohydrate, fat, protein, salt and sometimes umami/ glutamate. We are subconsciously wired to like these things. Our bodies are setup to respond to certain types of nutrients and create a motivation and learning response that prioritizes and sets the motivation level on seeking these types of foods.

title: Gut-Brain Signaling and Dopamine Mediated Reinforcement
content: Our bodies are wired around energy acquisition, in terms of our motivation and learning on a nonconscious level. Research since 2018 has shown that we have dedicated sensors in the small intestine called neuropod cells. They have receptors for specific nutrients and are directly hooked up to the vagal neurons. When they detect glucose (carbohydrates), amino acids (protein), or fatty acids (fat), they start sending signals up your vagus nerve to your brain stem.

title: Carnivore Diet and Weight Loss
content: People lose weight on a carnivore diet, is this the motivation for going on this diet? Why does it result in weight loss? Stephan speculates that a carnivore diet has multiple properties that make it an effective weight-loss diet. It has very little carbohydrates. Being on the extreme of the fat:carbohydrate ratio in either direction is more slimming than being in the middle. The variety of a carnivore diet is very low. You’re cutting out all the highly-processed, calorie-dense foods.

title: Biochemical Changes in Carnivore Diet
content: The obvious one is dyslipidemia. There’s a shift toward a ketogenic metabolism because of the fact that it’s very low carbohydrate. One of the downsides Stephan focused on in the review (that is downplayed by many advocates of the carnivore diet, including Paul Saladino), is the change in LDL cholesterol and LDL particle count. But a large increase in LDL-C raises red flags in terms of cardiovascular risk over the long run.

title: Energy Balance Model and Carbohydrate-Insulin Model
content: The 2 models are the carbohydrate-insulin model (promoted by David Ludwig) and the energy balance model (promoted by Kevin Hall). The most recent incarnation of the carbohydrate-insulin model is a lot more complex than previous one. The idea that there are things in the diet and in the environment that impact insulin signaling. And insulin signaling impacts body fatness. Downstream of the fattening process of insulin signaling on adiposity is the proposal that it leads to elevated calorie intake and possibly a decline in metabolic rate.

title: Energy Balance Model of Obesity
content: Energy balance is a result of brain activity which feeds into adipose tissue. Body fatness is kind of receiving the excess energy. Body fat is not really the driver of this process, but when excess energy enters the body, it’s what mops it up. The energy balance model is the conventional model; it says the reverse is happening. The input of fuels into the system leads to an increase in circulating metabolic factors that is now driving energy balance into the fat cell. The conventional model contends that fat tissue is simply a result of how many calories you happen to eat or how much you decide exercise. However the energy balance model acknowledges the brain regulation of both body fat and appetite. It contends that body fatness regulated by the energy intake and expenditure via the brain.

title: Carbohydrate-Insulin Model of Obesity
content: In the carbohydrate-insulin model, the idea is that the primary cause is the adipose tissue increasing in its fatness. The adipose tissue wants more energy; this is driven by external factors such as carbohydrates. Also in the drive to increase fatty acid deposition into adipose tissue is a reduction in circulating metabolic fuels and this drives an increase in appetite. Intake of food goes up to accommodate the reduction in circulating metabolic fuels. All feeding into a drive toward fatness.

title: Calories and Their Impact on Body Fat
content: The energy balance model does not consider all calories identical in terms of their impact on body fat. There may be different thermogenic effects and there may be different regulatory effects on appetite. You can change the diet composition and produce animals that will gain fat independent of calorie intake. This has been shown for carbohydrate quality and dietary fat.

title: Body Weight Set Points
content: The set point around which the lipostat regulates can change based on dietary and environmental variables. For example, if you take someone on a typical diet and put them on a low carb diet, you don’t have to tell them to reduce their calorie intake, that will occur spontaneously and they will lose fat and the typical person will end up being comfortable at a lower weight. They’re not experiencing a starvation response. You can see this on other diets as well. But changing the setpoint doesn’t mean a formerly obese person is cured; if they went back to their other diet they will generally go back to their former weight. The set point can be modified by a different environment. As long as you maintain that change, you can maintain the effect. But if the change goes away, then the effect goes away.

title: Weight Loss Through Gastric Bypass Surgery vs Diet and Lifestyle Changes
content: Gastric bypass is unique where by as long as the person doesn’t take in liquid calories, the weight loss is quite durable. Liquid calories can completely disrupt the feedback mechanisms, similar to a GLP-1 agonist. Anecdotally, patients who take semaglutide who don’t lose weight. The way you can cheat semaglutide is to drink a massive amounts of calories.

title: Takeaways for People Who Want to Lose Weight and Keep It Off
content: For people with a BMI of 30 or 35, it’s worthwhile to consider medical treatment. Something like semaglutide; it’s a very safe drug. It causes something on the order of 18% weight loss. This is better than the typical effect of diet and lifestyle strategies but you have to keep taking the drug. See an obesity specialist. For people who just want to lose a few pounds, your appetite and your body fatness are very much regulated by your brain. This is based on inputs your brain is receiving; a lot of this is nonconscious. Try to give the nonconscious brain signals to regulate things in a more slimming direction.

title: Satiety and Gastric Distention
content: Satiety is a function of gastric distention. This is important, but the system is complex; the brain is receiving a lot of signals. Signals from the small intestine about what the nutrient composition is. Oral sensory detection of food properties. Your brain knows based on the sensory properties what the nutritional composition of the food is based on prior experience. Stomach distention is a biggie, and this relates to calorie density. If you have a food that has more volume per calories, it fills up your stomach more and sends signals to oppose further food intake. Protein is more satiating per calorie. Palatability, the better something tastes the less it fills you up per calorie.

title: Evidence that Favors the Energy Balance Model of Weight Gain
content: One of the arguments in favor of the carbohydrate-insulin model is other examples of growth that are regulated from the hormones, out to the intake of energy. The central thrust of the carbohydrate-insulin model is, increased insulin signaling is driving an increase in food intake. This can be initiated by sleep disturbances that increase (or decrease) insulin signaling, or foods that stimulate insulin. Both models are not mutually exclusive. If you understand the mechanism of obesity, then it should be easier to address. Most obesity drugs (weight loss drugs) were discovered in haphazard ways. Rybelsus (Semaglutide) is a drug developed to treat obesity based on its mechanism of action, from the bottom up. It’s safe and effective. We’re in a new era where weight loss drugs are being designed based on mechanism and an understanding of biological regulation.

title: Functions of GLP-1 and GLP-1 receptor agonists
content: Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) on BMI point largely to genes involved in the brain. GWAS on body fat distribution (controlling for BMI and looking at the distribution of fat on the body) point to a insulin signal. This gives some support to the carbohydrate-insulin model. The total amount of body fat seems more related to energy intake; it’s regulated more on the intake side of the equation and somewhat by the brain. The carbohydrate insulin model is all about this idea of energy partitioning; there could be some of that flying under the radar of BMI.

title: Energy Partitioning and Obesity
content: Obesity is not just energy partitioning. You have a bigger body, you’re eating more energy, you’re burning more energy. You have more lean mass, more fat. That phenotype is not explained by energy partitioning. But there could be some subtle energy partitioning phenotype that is also operating.

title: Effects of Fat and Carbohydrates on Weight
content: The synergistic effect of fat and carbohydrates and observations that a low-fat diet or a low-carb diet can cause weight loss. For example, people on the potato diet (where all they eat is potatoes), lose weight like crazy. This has been shown in animal models. The advantage here is the ability to have really tight control on the diet for a large proportion of the animal’s lifespan.

title: Study on Dietary Fat and Energy Intake
content: John Speakman published a study of around 29 different diets and 5 different strains of mice. They systematically varied the carbohydrate to fat ratio in the diet. They asked, “How does that interact with body fatness?” They found mice got fatter with the more fat they ate, up to a point at which they began to lose weight.

title: Low Fat and Low Carb Diets
content: When people go on a very low fat or a very low carb diet, their energy intake declines by hundreds of calories a day. This happens automatically, right away. His thought is that food in these diets is less rewarding so we eat less of it.

title: Quality of Popular Nutrition Books
content: Most of his surprises were realizing the quality of popular nutrition books was worse than he thought. Peter is in the process of trying to finish his book; one of the things that is so daunting is the fact-checking process. He could never rely on his publisher for this, it’s too technical. He has analysts who fact check, but they have to be analysts who did not help with the research for the book because you’ve got to get fresh eyes on it. He just knows there’s going to be something they get wrong, incorrectly cite, or misinterpret.

title: Red Pen Reviews
content: Red Pen Reviews is a 501c3 nonprofit that publishes the most informative, consistent and unbiased reviews of popular nutrition books available. Developed by Stephan with the help of other academics; inspired by the nutrition scientist Seth Yoder. What makes this website unique is the semi-quantitative review method they developed and apply to each book. This yields a numerical score for scientific accuracy, reference accuracy, and helpfulness. This allows them to apply the same rigorous method to all books so the reader can compare apples to apples between different books.
